Recd aug 4/63
Mentions the clock
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

July 30th

My darling Johnny
how truly glad I was to receive your
little note today for verily you have
scarcely been out of my mind since I 
left you. I think over all my visit
think of the very dear sweet good
children and wish I could see them
often. cherish them and teach them
all that is good and generous and 
true - and for that you must go
to the fountain head, go to the work
of God. what can be better than the
instructions of our Creator. moreover
he has promised with his instruction
his blessing - even his powerful and
enlightening spirit - And with what
earnest anguish does my heart 
go out to God for his blessing on 
you & yours - As to our life's afflictions
are they not but as the - of the
balance compared to the joys of 
eternal life - May we live as to
meet our God & Saviour with joy -

I suppose when I wrote to Jane you read my letters. But n'importe they were not worth much. I never feel much like writing at first - but I suppose she told you of my reception. I did not know whether I ought to tell, but concluded you would want to know. But you must not any of you entertain unkind or improper feelings about these things I have ceased to suffer any more than the sorrow that sin is committed and that I am the occasion of it - it would be a great deal easier for me to bear all this if it did not cause my children to do or feel wrong - that is my trial. So keep quiet and feel good and all will yet be well. Jane suggests half or quite in jest that Mr Harding join your hunt and bring Nanny. She has been so sick for ten days and is so nervous - that she really

seemed to take up the idea with some earnestness.  Mr. H. says he will take her and have her while he goes to Phila - She says she will not think about it.  A letter from Frank to Romaine came to me yesterday as he did not know her address. They were between the Blue ridge and Bull run he was well - poor fellow - he has had a very severe time.  John Acheron is coming home on a visit.  Mr. & Mrs. Acheron have gone to see Sandy before he joins his regiment again and Mrs. A, feel as tho? she must see the battle field where Dave was killed. he was engaged to Jennie Macauly - and the poor girl is quite broken hearted. John is expected home with his father & mother next week.  he has been a long time on Folly Island.  I have sent Jane 3 papers today.

Mr. Harding & Pa have settled their accounts and Mr. H. has bought out Pa's interest. He gave him 20 p.cent for his money all his goods at cost and 1000 dollars.  His store he values at 10,000 and no debts.  Now he thinks a clothing store in his old room would be just the thing for Julius.  He told Pa so and Pa unclear would just be the thing for Julius.  Mr. H. says I ought to sell unclear house and invest his money in it. 2 or 3 thousand would be just what would do.  But he thinks Pa would let him have the money.  Mr. H. to have an unclear and teach him the business? - which is very easily learned but he would have to apply himself very differently to [[business?] and stick to it making 1000 or 1500 a year.  Mr. H thinks it a very fine offering and several persons have applied for it.  So there is no time to be unclear if you see Julius talk it over with him.  I don't know where to address him or would write immediately.  Sheep and wood are both down any how. it is a mean business.  Tell him to hurry home if he wants or let us know quickly. Much love to you all  your loving Mother. I think it would be better for Jane to have her teeth fixed? it is to be hoped Pa will pay. - Your clock? is gone.

John V Le Moyne Esq
Chicago
Illinois
Ma & Julius
Recd Sep 25.63

with much love to all
I am aff. yours
Julius
Dear Johnny.  I received your letter today and I had better answer it immediately as this promises to be a rather busy week.  Seminary examination and  Fair? occupying us for three? days but in fact monopolizing the whole week - I expect Julius and one of Annie's sisters will be here.  unclear family will be at Charlotte's - Lilly Finney? graduates and her friends will be in town.  Mrs. Pierpont? expects some friends from Wheeling that will expect some attention from us. So Sis at least will be entirely occupied there These little country festivals are very pleasant? to us and I think really beneficial.
Tomorrow I am to take tea at Mr. unclear with Mary & Mrs. unclear.  They returned on Thursday from their trip and enjoyed it very much - friends all so pleasant and Niagara fully realizing all expectations. Mary is very fine spirits, and busy Just commencing to Reef? house?

all happy and bright now. May it last. Pa wanted Julius to bring his horses to the fair - that he might show off Rale? and her five colts - if he does not come I will send him your note - but he is not going West again this winter - Mrs unclear & Charlie got home today greatly to my relief. Sophie has been very ill indeed so as to cause much alarm - and is not yet well enough to travel - if she be able they will all come on Thursday - or as soon after as Sophie can come - some disease of the stomach - her mouth & tongue were covered with blisters and sores and much swollen, so she could scarcely swallow - besides she was unwilling to take the medicine at first or use the water of unclear honey - she had very high fever, and unclear
she is a little better, able to walk about the room, but still very feeble and mouth very sore - I should have gone over if they had told me the worst -

At last we are having rains? but we have had a frost too that has unclear much damage- we have a unclear quantity of grapes & peaches that are unclear a few are ripe. as many as we eat. every day - I am with unclear Frank came to Washington City last week with unclear and unclear but I don't know where he remains with them. Mr Welch? has been prevented? from coming by himself- Mr. Ewing is going to see his daughter Mrs Shear?, at Lake City, below St. Paul-  as soon as the election is over he will go theo? Chicago. an a unclear to hunt you unclear Twice he a unclear  opportunity for Jane unclear is ready - or if she wants any thing sent - she must do just as she likes best. much love to you all. Here comes Lubi-- he will finish? then. Your loving Mother

Dear John
[Unclear} your note this evening just as I arrived home from Wallsbury? I was sorry that I did not see you but was in too much of a hurry to stop longer. I don't think now that I will be west again this fall. We started another lot of sheep last week.
The horse you speak of was a very fine one and of good blood he belongs to Mr [unclear] Morey of Clayton Ill he offered to trade him to me for $200.worth of sheep said he had been offered $100. cash. I think $175. would buy [unclear] [unclear] I came home I wrote [unclear] to trade for [unclear] at Moreys price but have heard nothing from him sinse about it. As soon as I know more I will write you again. The horse reminded me more of our old John [unclear] any horse I ever saw

John Le Moyne Chicago Illinois
Written on side
Ma Recd Sept 18 1863

I want to tell him how much Nicholas has made but I cannot get the chance ~ so he might take a notion not to speak to Jane~ as he never speaks of her -it is right not to publish McClellan report. it is so voluminous as to require an appropriation by every rep full of charts and diagrams & no manner of use to any body only to spend money ~ why don't he resign? when he knows he is will not be given a command.  He is mean to receive pay for nothing~

Dear Johnny I will tell you, but I don't know that you need tell Jane, but I have tried to talk to Pa about Jane several times, her teeth, what she has said &c&c but he never notices nor answers- except once he said much of what dentists did was useless.  I don't know that he knows that R. has been away and he would not let me tell him anything about Julius ~ nor have I mentioned you or Chicago or anything connected with my trip

Ma Rec'd Oct 7, 1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago, Illinois

Oct 3
Dear Johnny
I have not heard from you but presume you are all well and happy
Jane, it seems is still away ~it takes her gums a long time to heal don't it ~ o well
I suppose she is trying to indemnify herself for the sufferings of the past.  Julius and 
Mahala were here a day or two and he will be back to vote. We had a tremendous 
meeting. very respectable looking and well behaved. Gov said one of the finest in all respects
he had ever seen ~ yet our people feel as tho they must make every effort.
The Copperheads are so active and vigilant ~ and you know this has always been such a 
democratic strong hold ~ but let us hope and pray that the right may prevail and
freedom be established to all and forever ~ it seems to me I should be too happy if
the last brick of slavery were broken.  Romaine & family are here Nicolas & Mr Harding have been hunting

with, not very great success ~
we have a great many peaches & grapes ~
grapes, I suppose will continue yet 
a while but peaches are just done ~
why don't you plant plenty of peaches
I do believe they would grow ~ fill your 
lot with fruit.  I have saved you some stones
of very good peaches - but after all I 
expect Michigan fruit would suit your
climate better ~ Romaine and all enjoyed
their sojourn very much, but they were 
thoroughly convinced of New England's
harsh and inhospitable clime and
barren soil. the sea was grand
novel to them, fish & lobster, huckleberry
and cream, all very good eating ~ hit
the rough and changing climate with
its mysians of mosquitoes must have
been more than an equivalent ~ Boston
too, whose distance had so enshrined
it in enchantment, and near approach
lost all its charms ~ and like other
great cities, appeared full of all

manner of iniquites ~ so they come
home quite satisfied that Pittsburg
is quite a habitable place ~ so we must
conclude the book is wise, that says all
have dinned and come short of the 
glory of God if communities be corrupt
the individuals that compose them
cannot be very pure ~ hence the necessity
of being renewed.  Nanny is better
since her return ~ but was much alarmed
about Sophie ~ she too is well now, but
I think Nanny would be afraid to 
leave home again just now.
I will try to send you a paper about the fair
& prem..?. Jane may like to see it ~
we were to be entwined by a party
next wee ~ at the Seminary ~ but Dr.
Hanna? had an attack of paralarys
a day or two since, so I suppose that
will stop proceedings ~
Romaine asked Pa to let Sis go home
with her and make her a visit
he said he would see about it that

she was doing nothing here only loafing about
she told him  she wished to put 
her thru a course of music? to which
he made no objection ~ so they all 
take it for granted she is going ~ 
Pa seems quite pleased? with
Minie & Jane and thinks the boy
the best to keep of all and quite a 
substantial fellow ~ Sis objects to
leaving me alone ~ as she don't want
to go unless she can stay awhile ~ 
but I think I can get along very well
if I can't, why I can send for her or Jane
but I hope now they can go as often as
they please. that is the desideratum for
which I have waited. I expect Sis will
be permitted to visit you next summer
or should Jane come this winter? She
can go back you see, we take it for 
granted, you want us ~ perhaps you can
all come to us by that time ~ much love to
all, big and little ~ an even dear Johnny
Your loving Mother
Nicolas talks of going to Saginaw Thursday after the election

Ma Rec'd Oct 23, 1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago, Illinois

Oct 20
Dear Johnny,
I have not heard from you for a long time
Are you all well.  I have just returned from
a very pleasant visit to Annie. Julius took me
over in a buggy and brought me to Wheeling
in the cars and I came from there alone.
I could have come all this way but he would 
come. I enjoyed the ride there very much
the woods were in their height of beauty~
the road excellent and the weather alright
~ but ~ they seemed very glad to see me
and all vied with each other to make me comfortable.
It was truly delightful to walk
thro the orchard gatherings nice big apples
and over those great high hills 
an the fallen leaves ~ it seemed to me I have never
seen hills before ~ so high, so steep, and so 
many ~ in fact nothing but hills ~ Mr Kuhn's
house is on a very high one that commands
a view of the town, rail roads and all 
the country round.  I found them in the
midst of apple butter making ~ of which they
had 27 gallons ~ then they have 27 barrels of
apples.

for winter use, berries, much cider and
then they will sell the rest ~don't you wish you
had such an orchard. those hills are only fit
for orchards vineyards or sheep ~ but Julius
likes Washington County better than Brooke
he has been to see Moningeragain and he is to give
a decided answer this week. I feel very sure
he will not sell.  Romaine was at Belle Ewings
the other day and heard that the adjoining
farm was for sale ~ they will be at Mr Kuhn's
until Annie gets well again and probably
until Spring ~ I found all at home rather 
sad.  Pa had refused to let Sis go ~ giving as a
reason that Nicolas had behaved strangely to 
him. tho he had been in to see him 
several times so N. went to him and told
he had no intention of giving any offence 
or of being disrespectful &c Pa expressed
himself satisfied &c but when Romaine
asked him this morning he refused saying
it was no use. people should not go where 
they have no business ~ so poor Sis is very
much disappointed_ and we are all very

very sorry for her. perhaps when Jane comes
we may be able to get her off if be
only to Wellsburg with Julius ~ you can 
not imagine what a delightful relief to
get away from such offensive sway
every place is so delightful and free ~
I do not feel like the same person ~ I have
the same reception as before ~ but it is
wearing off ~ I did not hear from Frank
last week but hope his letter is only miscarried.
we had quite an exciting time last week
with our elections but all is quiet now.  I suppose
you are satisfied of McClellan's loyalty now
the Copperheads exalted greatly over his
letter and had his name on their banners-
I suppose Jane will be with you by the
time this reaches you. I send her things
by Romaine. I wish I could send you
some grapes. we have more than we can
use and there are still some on the vines ~
for Jane's benefit ~ Mary Adams was married
to Sam. Court this morning and started
for Denver City where they all live, and

Matty McCasky to Dan. Valentine who is
clerk in Smith's store ~ a tea party
this evening at Dr.McKennan's for Mary
Bureau.  Just received a letter from
Frank dated 15th at Fairfax where they have 
just arrived after reconnoitering and skirmishing - 
and well
Much love to you all
As ever your loving Mother
Romaine goes tomorrow. We had a nice visit from her and they have all enjoyed 
it.  Mr Wills will go next week
and Charlotte will remain sometime
yet perhaps a month
Where is Alex Guthrie

Ma
Recd Nov 10, 1863
Mr John Le Moyne
Chicago, Illinois

Oct 6th
Dear Johnny,
Perhaps you will not thank me for writing
this evening, but the fact is I don't feel
like doing any thing else. I have been in
a rather unsettled state for two days
and slept very little last night~ it is 
foolish and yet it is   ~ yesterday Julius
and Nicolas very unexpectedly made their
appearance from Wellsburg ~ they were
coming to attend the sale of Mrs Frisbie's
farm and Nicolas was anxious too
to take Sis back ~ they told their business
and plans to Pa ~who will not exactly
think as they did but after the while
seemed in a good humor so today
I asked him to let Sis go. No. No. 
I said do let her she wants to so much
and needs a little visit ~ I don't care
she will not go. How sadly disappointed
were we, but I did not tell Sis.
Well the sale came off. When the bill
ran up to 80 dol an acre, Julius & Nicolas

withdrew. Mr. McGiffin then & there
offered them his for the same, which
very? acceptable and unclear being 200 
acres it costs 16,000 dols. Mr McG's
health is very bad and he cannot
attend to his farm or he says, no 
money could buy it. It has a new 
barn & stable ~ the old house repaired
an orchard planted ~ some treas
bearing Julius is to live on it an 
improve it and pay taxes and keep
all he makes ~ he is quite pleased
and I know Annie will be.
And now Charlotte will buy his house ~
and Mr Harding wants Hay's ~ so we
seem to be settling.  David Morgan
bought Mrs Frisbee's at 80 dols
10.00 and more. He owns a small
farm adjoining ~ part of the old Scott
farm. I suppose Jane has left you
we shall be place to see her, but I hope
she is prepared for whatever is before 
her.

Mr Wills was gone when your letter
arrived but it has been forwarded.
I hope Mr Byrd is loyal if not he should
not come North. I want you to get
Mr. Mark's book and read it~
I always forgot to tell you to rack
your vinegar and if it be not strong
enough put in a good piece of Mother.
Give much love to the dear children
and accept a goodly portion for your
dear self from your loving Mother
Maddy Langley has a daughter

Nov. 14th
Dear Johnny    I don't think you 
deserve a birth day letter and I don't
think I feel like writing one.  I need
not tell you this is your fortieth birthday ~
you would not believe me.  but if I tell
you forty times how much your Mother
loves you will you believe that ~ you have
children of your own now and you know
she can not help loving you yes and 
yours too~ I hope you are all very well
and happy. The boys I suppose are going
to study hard this winter. well they will 
enjoy it, when they get a little farther on.
Children are much happier when their
time is wholly occupied ~ idleness is
truly the mother of mischief ~ I am pleased
to see that your Fair has been so successful ~
really, it does not look much like
hard times~ send me a paper with some
account of it ~ I received one with the
account of the bridge accident ~
Jane is not yet come ~ she expects to

go to Wellsburg next week. all is well
there yet. Jane's visit may be very 
opportune she is very anxiously 
awaited here by numerous interested
ones ~ Charlotte will go to Pittsburg next
week and Sis or Tom will keep house for
her 2 or 3 weeks. she may then go to
Washington. The children are very unwilling 
to go they would prefer remaining there at
school. Mr Wills may have to go to Memphis~
in that case she will wait his return ~
Julius wants to sell is house for 3,000 
dols. but Charlotte thinks that too much
so she may not buy it ~ Pa was not much
pleased with your letter ~ but I suppose
he will speak for himself ~
His farming operations keep him very
busy ~ he has not yet sold his wool
I think he expects to get a dollar for it
I intended sending you a large photograph
of Sis and let you get it painted but it
is not a very clear one. Charlotte 
and Nicolas had them taken and

gave me one. Mrs Lee painted Nicolas
and Romaine thinks it lovely ~
We have just had a visit of two days
from Rebecca Danner. her two boys have
graduated at Beloit College. Edgar is
studying divinity in N. York city at
Columbia College ~ Julius is teaching
the high school at Palmyra, Ill but
intends going to Chicago to study law
he is a very good clever fellow, pleasant
and kind ~ which is in your family 
& office what Alex was.  Mr Danner
has a situation with some of the Guthries 
or unclear in Mansfield 
where they are going to live. he has been
the last two years with Mr Guthrie in
Putnam. I had a letter from Frank since
the battle. His Corps, the 6th since the fighting
but his division,  3rd was not ordered in, tho
drawn up and witnessed the whole.
Nanny and Mr Harding are both sick with influenza.

Much love to you all
Let me hear from you often
How are the Julias
I intended writing to dear Franky
but have been prevented ~
As ever and forever your loving
Mother
Get the Atlantic for Nov and a true 
story called the Brothers

Ma
Recd Nov 29/63
John Le Moyne
Chicago, Illinois

Nov 23rd
Dear Johnny,
At last we have our dear Janey 
safe and sound and to all appearance
happy and pleased once more to take
her place among us. You have all been
very kind and loving to her and I am
sure she appreciates your kindness 
and returns your love ~ every one of you
she only reached home on saturday evening
we were looking for her and were  all
glad to see her~ one of her greetings was
cool and quiet, tho rather pleasant.
I thought you knew that Nor..? McGiffin
unclear on the old Thurston farm'
There is where Nicolas has bought ~ the
house is old but comfortable ~ he has
added Dr. Stevens' lot to his property so
that he joins Fitzwilliams and Pa
I am sorry about your vinegar ~ the
reason for racking is that the sediment
decays and spoils it

dear Johnny I began this, night before last
and was interrupted by company and have
been prevented finishing.  Jane is much
occupied receiving calls and making them
besides sundry other important affairs
yesterday a letter from John's announced the 
important event of the birth of a daughter
black hair and brown eyes and 
Annie as well as could be expected after
the awful ordeal. we were rejoiced knowing
their great anxiety  Charlotte went to Pittsburg
this morning taking Franny & leaving Willie. Sis
is keeping house for her ~ another large splinter 
came out of her hand about an inch long making
the 4th~ the pictures are lovely and natural
I do wish I had a good one of their Mother ~
Much love to her and all.  I really believe
Jane will soon get homesick for Jule she
says she will hate to leave the children
she will write as soon as she gets a little time
Your loving Mother

Ma
Recd Jany 2, 1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago, Illinois

Decr 29th
Dear Johnny
You are always dear Johnny and 
always remembered and often mentioned
but it is not so easy always to sit down and
commit all one's feelings & thoughts together.
I really think I a getting too old to write
many letters but not to read them over too
So ? to love my darling children and
their own little ones ~ what bright and
living streams of joy are those precious little
ones ~ and how thankful am I for them.
truly my cup of blessings overflows
May they all be transferred to the
garden of the Lord when they have
served their time in this world.
St. Nicholas was liberal to our children
for which they are duly thankful and with
which they seem quite satisfied and
happy ~Nanny expressed herself as being
'so happy; she wished every day was
Christmas indeed all seemed to enjoy
the occasion.  Julius and Annie
and Lizzie were in and all

were merry we dined at Charlotte's
and Pa seemed to partake of the 
general good humor.  I have notified
him that we must have a turkey for 
New Year's day so you see we are 
like the children of Job - feasting in each other's
houses~ Julius will leave the farm on
the first of April.  Reese the man of 
all work, takes the farm and goes into
the house ~ the other farms are all 
rented so Julius will probably come
into town and board with Charlotte.
he expects to find something to do ~ he is
acting according to advice
I don't think it would be better for Frank
to go into the army, unless it be to do
good if he be needed but what
does he need with so much surgery
in common practice ~ he had better try
to get into some hospital ~ the length of 
the war will depend upon the principles
on which it is prosecuted ~ if justice
and freedom mark out the line and
it be carried out with firmness and

energy it will be short
very much depends on the coming proclamation
the reason we have not succeeded is that
the Nation was not ready - it had to be 
schooled and enlightened and whipped
in - but let us hope all will come right.
Charlotte will probably go the second week in
January Jane will go to Pittsburg with her
and I expect she will find her way to Chicago
some time this winter so if you know of
any company be sure to let her know.
Pa said she was of age and could do as she 
pleased.  I felt sure there would be no
opposition. I suppose she will be back
by the first of May unless she get homesick
sooner.  I am glad she is going. she needs
it so much she has so much sickness
lately  I feel anxious about her and shall
be uneasy until I hear she is safe and sound 
with you.
Our little ones are again at school.  Sophie
says she and Charley only go one day at a
time while at the unclear school

they go two days together - she means 
they go but once a day - she is a funny
little thing -quite original and lively and
full of fight and fun.
Much love to you all dear Johnny
Many a merry christmas and happy
New Year to you all from your
loving Mother
Dear John are you very seriously
offended at me?  If you are I
shall not dare to present myself in
Chicago this winter.  I always
was afraid of angry people 
and could not think of travelling
all that distance unless I was 
sure of a warm reception. They
want me in North East to spend
the winter.  Shall I go?
Yours dubiously!
Jane

Ma
Recd 
Jany 2 1864
John Le Moyne
Chicago, Illinois

Decr 28th
Dearest Johnny
I made up mind two weeks ago
to write to you the first leisure
time I had. so, this evening finding myself
alone and at leisure, I begin, not
knowing, however whether I shall finish
well we have had dear Franky and
he was in hopes you & Romaine could 
come ~ as he only had 15 days ~ we
made the most of him ~ the children
big & little amused themselves in the
frolics of the season ~ making and sending
little gifts ~ perpetrating practical jokes 
o.c. the dinner was at Charlotte's~
I have great reason to think myself
an especial favorite with Krish Kindle
as he quite overwhelmed me with his
munificence ~ according to previous
arrangement, Nanny invited me &
Frank & Julius to tea, having made
my visit I returned to find a nice
new carpet on my room ~ the gift of

Romaine - it had come some days 
previous and had been made at 
Mrs Harding's store ~ they all enjoyed
my surprise as much as I admired
their secrecy - for even the children
all knew it but never gave me a 
hint of it- a box of animals of
various kinds, fruit trees and such
things as are required on a farm
were sent to Nicolas~ a box of (toy)
furniture to Nanny- a large old
book full of pictures of cats to Jane
as she had asked for Kitto's illustrations.
there by way of joke - but by way 
of gifts - Jane & Sis received a lot of
beautiful and valuable books from
Nicolas, with the others -Nanny and
Sis had knit muffs, mittens and
ear-warmers to send to your children
thro Mrs Murray but Romaine
did not let us know about it. I had
directed her to make a contribution
to Mrs Murray's box for me too-

but have not heard from her -
Frank is very well and I never saw
him so fat. he weighs 163. says their
regiment will not reenlist so unless he
leave it he will be home in May-
says nine soldiers out of ten are
for Lincoln ~ good ~ yes that
takes me back to McClellan's
nomination. I was truly glad to 
see him nominated by the conservatives ~
who are only one remove from
secesh ~ he could not have chosen a 
surer death ~ I am not so sufficiently 
satisfied with honesty as to wish to
exchange it for dishonesty  ~ to say the least
I am a radical ~ I want every root 
of the disorder eradicated ~ I always
thought Lincoln too slow but perhaps
he moved as fast as public sentiment
would let him. He will go faster next
time. Julius left us this morning
he is not in very good spirits just now
he lost one of his fine horses ~ Starlight ~

he broke his leg so badly they had to shoot him.
then he may be drafted.
he cannot go~ and substitutes are high
Charlotte will buy his house for 3500 ~
Nanny has to home where she is and will
probably go in with Charlotte until
they can buy or rent ~
Jane seems to enjoy herself ~ and is
pretty well ~ but we do feel that it was too
much for you to pay for her teeth.  I have
never thanked you for my pretty and some
of them, precious presents ~ the pictures
are too sweet and lovely ~ every now & then
I take them out and look at them and say
ain't they sweet ~ deer children I do love
them dearly ~ the work box is rather wonderful
but very pretty ~ Old Mrs Morgan
(David M's Mother) died this morning
76 years old.  A telegram from Frank
announces all right in W.
The went by the Bal & O. RR.  Much love to you all
with the congratulations of the season and
all manner of good for the future.
Your loving Mother

Ma
Recd Feb 10/64
John Le Moyne
Chicago, Illinois

Feb 6th
Very dear Johnny  It is not anything
new to say I was glad to hear from you 
is it ~ but I am sure you will believe me
when I say it- glad too that you were all
well and not frozen up.  I really was anxious
about you that very cold weather.  I read
of 3 little boys being frozen in sight of their
home coming from school and then I thought
of my 3 little dears in that terrible climate
finally I concluded if any of you were frozen
your names would be mentioned.  hope 
you have got your box and that the boys
will find the ear warmers comfortable.
I hear from Charlotte often - the children are
anxious to come home ~ Sarah invites them
to her house and they go sightseeing.  Mr
Wills has three suits in the Supreme Court.
Frank is still at Manasses - tho his 
promotion appointed him to a Cavalry Co -
Julius was here for a week and went
for Annie to be here next tuesday
they will go into Charlotte's house

March 29th
Dear Johnny  I have only just received yours of the 20th 
the first thing that strikes me is that we shall never agree
in politics.  I am intensely antislavery and consider slavery
the curse of our land and sole and entire cause of this terrible
war. and nothing but its entire abolition can secure peace
for that reason I cannot - bear with Mc Clellan.  he never
was any thing but proslavery - guarded rebel property and
favored rebels - I believe him to be an unclear coward.
If he has abilities has never shown, except in engineering
and finishes by endorsing Woodward, who thinks the rebels
ought to be conciliated - did not write his letter untill
assured the Copperheads would win the elections-
as to his report - I m far from reading it. I really thought
it an imposition to print it.  No I never wait to hear of
McClellan in any public capacity - I make every allowance
for your partiality from your natural
aprehensiveness? in friendship - once a friend always so-
besides dear Johnny, you know you don't trouble yourself
much about politics indeed I don't consider any man
very loyal who is not antislavery- Just hope you don't think 
so now - but you will after a while.
Did I not tell you why Jane went to Pitts. I suppose I
thought Romaine would tell you - she & the children
were all sick with whooping cough & colds and WIllie took spasmy
and Nicolas was away so Julius took Jane over and she
remained until they all got better and Charlotte came
and she has been sick ever since - Willie is here and
Fanny with her mother.

Charlotte is a little better and will probably not come untill
Wednesday with Pa. who has actually gone to Washington with- 
Maj Mc F. and Mr. Ewing to try to get a tariff on foreign wool.
he went this morning by the cars and will return same way -
our parlor was cleaned yesterday. has a fire today and Jane and
Sis are to have full sweep - tomorrow is contest - something to
the young people you know, and thursday morning Mary Acheson
is to be married to Billy Child? homoepath physician. Pitts -
and the girls, and Annie & Julius all invited and if the weather
be pleasant and Sis gets a good opportunity she may go to
Pittsburg and come back with Pa!  would it not be nice-
they gave a concert in Alexander and made 100 dol and had
a very nice time. entertained by the first people there. alltogether
they have made rather more than 400. besides expenses and they
were rather heavy - but they enjoyed themselves, and sounded
the patriotic feelings of the peoples- judging by the immense applause
and enthusiasm of their audiences. They were invited to Wheeling

poor woman in the midst of her labors. Tom encamped to

When he went without their knowledge or consent - I think that 
was hard but he says he knew they would not consent and
he felt as tho he must go.  he was ashamed to stay at home -

May 7th
Dear Johnny-  I have just been hunting a 
sheet of paper to write to you when I received your letter, one
week almost, after date - I was glad to get it and would have
written to you sooner, but I have been sick for five or six weeks
part of the time not able to go out, but most of the time
dragging myself around as long as able, lying down often, but
too stupid and dull to write letters- I realize the full
meaning of the expression, powerful weak - and I am 
so very tired and weary - you know I always have such
attacks in the spring - but as I grow older of course they
increase in intensity -I used to think that with the
diminution of the process of resistance there would be
also less suffering - but it is just the reverse- the disease
or pain, the attacking force - overpowers the frail and
unresisting body - the only compensation is in the soul's
strength increasing in the same ratio that the body
decreases - but I do want to see all my children serving
their Maker and earnestly seeking the Kingdom of Heaven
O may we all be a happy family in eternity. I think very 
much of all the dear little ones - and every new comer
finds a warm place in my affections - if I could only go to
see you as I go to Julius' every day, almost - Kiss Rose ann,
talk to Annie, look at Julius in his field ploughing or
planting - rest awhile and walk home, then I am
ready for a good nap before dinner- so with reading
the paper, going a few times across the street to see 
Charlotte & Nanny - tho time passes - Charlotte bought Mrs Marshel's?
old horse & carriage, perhaps I told you, so I ride every day -

Julius has been very busy all spring - Nicolas was here about
two weeks and they have planted several hundred trees.
about 60 or 70 pear trees many of them dwarfs - the old 
darky who works for him, says he has polluted the farm
with fruit trees- today they finished putting in their 
potatoes - they have two fresh cows and expect to sell
about 12 pds of butter a week. it is 30 cts now - but of course
will come down - they will have no fruit this year except 
a few cherries- we have plums & pears no peaches and
I fear no apples as the blossoms are not yet out - but they
say apples are not killed - many peach trees were rotten
we still have several boxes of honey two years old -
I have filled you two cans of molasses - our camp was
put out on the shares one we expected to have ten
gallons - but only got five, tho it was a good season.
Cause? cheating. Pa does not find it very justifiable-
farming by proxy - his cattle are getting so poor
he is going to bring them to the hill and we will make our own butter.
Charlotte has a fresh cow and is churning too - sometimes their
winter butter sold for 25 but generally 35 we did not
buy it - but as generally the case, I know some poor people
who gave that - I must rest now - good night darling _
Sunday.  Not being able to go to church I will chat a little with you
dear Johnny - it is Sis' birthday 8th she is 21 and quite
happy in the idea of being of age- I don't imagine she will
have any trouble in asserting her independence - I really believe
Pa feels that he has gone a little too far - and that the loss has
been greater than the gain -

Nanny is fixed and comfortable - they like their house very
much, it is pleasant but rather small  it is very nice for
me to see them all from my windows - even Julius working in
his fields - and just now every thing is budding into beauty - 
yesterday Sis went with a fishing party to Taylortown on the
cars - and had a delightful time of course - but the fish
were scarce- coming back in the cars were Mr Harding and
Mr Wills - Mr W came by the B&O and was just behind
the train that was captured by the guerillas on Wednesday

number of federal soldiers all armed!! on their way

news of battle has just reached us - what a terrible suspense

and am trying the strawberry
cure - which seems to succeed to 
admiration - as I really date
my improvement to that enjoyment
I have been out very little to the
fair once for half an hour, when
I became so worried I had to come
out

I went to several evening entertainments

from Phila. which greatly disappointed
my expectations - tho people
seemed pleased.  Today we went to

the intelligence that George Weyman,
an intimate friend of Nicolas & 
Romaine, was dying.  Romaine
left us and hastened into town -
yesterday he was in his usual health

some affection of the head lately - 
he was a moral intelligent young

a christian untill within a few
days - when light seemed to shine
into his soul - after a long period of
struggle and anxiety -  Sandy
Acheson is at home wounded he

is to unite with the church on
next sunday - you know he was
pretty wild and has been drinking
since he went to the army -
I was quite surprised when I 
called on Mrs Murray to find she

not gone when you had such
a house full - the last letter we
had from Frank was dated 
June 4th Bottom's Bridge, he

times, much fighting and severe

we took one little trip to Altoona
and returned next day - 
Nicolas wanted Sis to see the

very much. and they thought a

short ride would do me good
and I think it tho I was very
tired and felt as tho I could not

has been with us several days and

I will stay a day or two longer-

so we are not prepared to

suppose Jane has written you
home news - all here are well
Nicolas is just as kind as it

He will be sadly shocked at

are both in town - much love to

August 9th
Dear Johnny - yours is received
and finds me still on my back and
as feeble as ever.  My cough is much
better, but my breast not - and some
days today for instance.  I am not able
to sit up but very little- until now unclear
tomorrow I may be a little better -
I cannot ride more than a mile out
and have not walked to the corner
yet. My appetite is more natural tho
not very voracious - but I have taken
no medicine at all except something
to alleviate the cough which I discontinued
after a day's trial - since that I 
have taken nothing - untill today when
Pa prepared me some drops of which I
am to take twenty, 4 times a day. I am
waiting positively for cooler weather the
heat oppresses me sadly - Wm. Harding
walked too soon and for the last two
weeks has been suffering from an
inflammation of the nerves & muscles

of the calf of his leg.  He could not move
and suffered terribly - from inflammation 
blisters, etc. yesterday and today he is
better and I suppose will now get well
I am too much worried about politics
every thing is going wrong and Old Abe
in the lead - I am out with him
altogether since his retrograde in the 
emancipation policy - if Fremont will
utterly abolish slavery and hang all
traitors I will go for him. yes, even
for McClellan if he would do the same
as to the poor fellows who were under
their first fire, they did no more than
their white skinned masters have 
often, often done and it is the first
instance of black soldiers failing -
but I see another cause of failure 
stated - that alters the complexion -
but because men have always been slaves
and refuse to fight for their masters -
(for what else are we?) is no reason
why they should remain slaves.

You would not fight under their
circumstances - not one in a hundred
of our noble race -
Frank has been placed over two
camp hospitals- has 3 medical
officers under him and 171 patients
says the country is polluted with
carrion - and flies - but he thinks
when he gets fixed and purified
he will be rather comfortable
all things considered, he is on the bank
of the river at Lighthouse point -
much love to you all
Your loving Mother -

this evening- Rose is not very well 
and I want to go out and see how
she is.  I think she is taking

Ma is not well today - Every now
and then she has a bad turn but

Poor Mr Harding has had a

Dear Johnny
It is a longtime since I received your
letter, and I have often thought & talked
of writing but could not - yet you are
dear to me Johnny and I feel a deep interest
in you & yours - yes a Mothers interest
never flags in any of her children
since the receipt of your last I have
been sick again - but am better now
tho far from well. My breast still
troubles me much and I am still in 
the doctor's hands - tho I seldom cough
I am very thin and not gaining - not yet
able to walk more than two squares -
but I pray not for life - but for a
preparation to die - Next sunday is
our communion.  Charlotte & Romaine
will be with us.  O if all my children
would meet me where there will be
no more trouble or sin or death -
but one eternal day of joy and
happiness - the desires and prayers

of my whole life would be answered.
God is omnipotent as well merciful His
will be done.  I suppose you have heard
of Fred Barlow's death - he was on the 
Tecumseh and lost - you know how
she went down he had been on an other
boat. but Farragut who had before
complimented him highly, chose him 
and 11 others to go on the Tecumseh
and all were lost.  another young man 
whom you may have known, from
Middletown, James Kelly - Poor Mrs
Barlow is here now in very deep grief
night before last his trunk came
which was a great trial to her to see
and then - Sam Potter was brought home
dead a few days ago - he was Frank's
hospital steward.  Jane's nephew.
I wish your boys could have been here

drying them- our grapes are ripinning

late.

Well even I was surprised at his

but it is all better so - better to be

the representative of true & loyal
principles of course he must have the
support of even loyal man - he will

Dearest Johnny We are again alone - we have seen all our dear
children and they are gone but it is a matter of unspeakable comfort
that we have hopes of enjoying that pleasure again - O is not hope
the anchor of the soul on which it can rest and wait patiently-
it is my greatest comfort for the present - Romaine left us
yesterday much improved, but still coughing occasionally.
she thought when she came that her cough was settled and
had very little hope of its leaving her - I am so glad she did
stay and have a nice visit- Poor William left with her -
his health is very bad, worse than ever- he is very thin
and feeble and cannot walk up to the Valentine without
resting- he rode out often with Charlotte & Willie -
he says he is a little better than when he left California
he then parted with John without the expectation of ever seeing
him again - he left because of the climate is too cold
the days are hot but the nights always very cool-
he came to this country on business and to see Charlotte & Willie
I expect he is settling up - he seemed to feel very badly at leaving 
Charlotte told him if he would stay she
would take a house and take care of him or she would go
wherever he thought he could live and take care of him -
he said o that would be too much happiness and what
he had always wanted - a home- but still he would not
let her do it - I told him if he would stay, we would nurse
him & put him up all we could - but he thinks it would be
certain death to remain here and he hopes that in a warmer
climate he may get a little better - he asked Pa what he thought

Pa told if he could get a good comfortable home he had
better stay in it- he did not think going would do any good-
sometimes he has such difficulty of breathing he cannot converse
I don't believe he is alltogether satisfied with John's success it is
seems John has been speculating and as usual without success
he thinks he might succeed very well if he would only quit
speculating - and thinks it would be a good thing to get him
in with Uncle Vinton - but Mr Vinton has a partner who is
now in Europe so he cannot tell whether he can take him or not
for my part I think Chicago would suit him  much better
I don't believe the climate would hurt Charlotte and as to dear
little Willie his chance is rather slim any where - William
was pleased that Willie loved him, thought him precocious and
very like his father, but think he will not live to grow up-
Willie has had a cold & cough for several weeks but is getting better
he & Charlotte are gone to the farm with Pa today-
Julius was with us several days last week- he had a boil
so that he could neither sit nor walk much- Pa scolded me
very much about his coming said he should not loaf about
here nor come to town so often - if he was sick let him
stay where he had chosen his home & etc. of course I did not
tell the poor child - but he wanted to go back the next
day, saying, Pa looked so cross - but he was not able and
I would not let him - Mama says he may stay there
whenever he wants to - I think we can manage to keep him
in the back ground awhile - until the storm blows over
(again) - Julius is not the first who has been in a state of 
rebellion - so I lean upon my old anchor, hope.
he is still much pleased - and is to be in several days

this week at the fair and cattle show - the Committee want 
him in the office so I expect he will feel as big as any of them- 
Mr Harding has been to Phila several times of the principal merchants
there have promised to see them thro - so he bought goods and
is not going to fail. and if he is to be restricted in his
visits he will be worried - for he resents any interference
and refuses to dodge? about - will do the thing openly
and honorably or not at all - he is very candid and often
artless and good humored and was taken quite aback
by the interdiction - the only thing we blame him for, is not talking
to Pa - he says if it was any other man in town he would not hesitate
but the fact is he is afraid of the Dr.  - however I think he 
will serve? up his courage and they will probably be married about
the middle of Oct. and go on with Charlotte - Sara invited him
to make her a visit but he thinks he will not have time - he will only
spend one day with his friends near Ellicott's Mills - they are beginning
with the determination to be very economical & industrious-
I conclude Nanny's heart is deeply interested when she faces
poverty & labor so willingly and valiantly - and if so and
she thinks him smart enough & good enough, at her age
I think I have nothing to say - I suppose they will board this winter
I would like to have them Mama's house - Nanny says she would like
it if Pa would fix & furnish it - leaving as much to Mama as she
would want of course.- not live with her - won't we have a
dreadful small family this winter.
The Will suited pretty well but I cannot leave out my dear
boys - they must come in for an equal share and if they do not
need it - they can give it to those who do - then the property may
be sold at any time - not wait for Jane or Sis to come of age
or money -

I wish you had advised me about that land business - Pa refuses
to have any thing to do with it - Will not give Naret the
deed he wants - so I suppose I can do nothing - Naret is
mad about it for he expected to make money selling the lands -
I told Sarah to let me know what she did with her Father's 
advice - She is still in Zanesville and will return this
week - We have had delightful weather - and quantity of flowers
and plenty of fruit - our apples are dropping off continually
the baking apples are enormous, wine apples very large and
beautiful - hardly ripe enough to be good and our peaches
are just beginning to ripen- the trees are breaking down
but the fruit is not very good and rotting on the trees - 
We have a bushel of dried corn boxed ready for you
and will send it soon - we have very few grapes
but Mama has a good many - scarcely ripe - plenty of
damson plums - I wish we could share our fruit
with you - we are eating some fruit all the time-
I thought I had told you of Mrs Acheson's death - she died
shortly before Annie, who was at her funeral, quite smart

Keisler's have sold to Marshal Hays for 1500  dollars they are

We are in hopes that William Wills will go to Florida with Mr Walter Marshal
of Pittsburg who as to leave on account of his health -

Your own affectionate mother

Nov. 7th
Dear Johnny- I have been thinking about you a great deal lately and intending to write, but I am getting lazy I know and cannot neglect dear Franky- he is very well and large. I don't know that it is fat- but he is said to weigh 175. He has rejoined his regiment once as they were about moving he may be on the south side by this time- Mr Wills goes back the day after the election tomorrow he goes to Pitsb. to make a speech Charlotte & Sis will go too for 3 or 4 days- Jane is very unwell most of the time - her old complaint of nervousness and wakefulness- I have had another bad cold and still cough and have pain in the breast, but as my appetite is good and I can now walk over the hills, I am only half an invalid, but am still taking cough drops. I generally take them a week and then stop, get worse, and begin again. I hardly expect to get rid of my cough but consumption is no worse than other things

not half as bad as some.  So I am content.
I shall not be taken till my work is done
and then I want to go- life is only given
us to prepare for eternity, else it would 
be a poor home- to love God supremely
and serve him perfectly is certainly far
better than to fight with sin all our
lives- Nicolas thinks he will go to see
Frank- Julius would go with but then
Frank is coming home at Christmas for
a few days- Julius' crops all did well
all things considered - the season was
not very propitious -his hay did not turn
out quite as good as he expected - yet not
bad. his potatoes of which he has 300 bushel
are rotting - but he has plenty of everything
else for man & beast. he expects to have at
least 2 barrels of sorghum molasses - two or
3 dozen brooms, a cellar full of apples he
gathered on Pa's farm - on the shares -so he
has plenty and some things to spare -
we have quantities of apples & some cider
and have made apple butter - and dried apples -

had plenty of grapes. They are done now I am trying to save a few for Frank- how often have I wished for the dear children to eat grapes & apples- Mrs. Harding has not entirely recovered- we had a terribly exciting time yesterday the Copperheads had a meeting procession & speeches by George Morgan & Bowen, Sweitzer etc all quiet enough untill about 5 except a few rowdyisnes by some of them. at that time Dick Fitzwilliams was sitting at Sweeney's door talking with some of the family when Ben. Brady (who has been the hero of all our shooting affairs) came up the street with two or three of his companions - turned the corner of the alley, and called to Dick to come to him. he had something to say to him. Dick refused to go. Telling him he could say it there and rose to go into the store whereupon  Ben fell to pounding and kicking him, knocked him down and abused him dreadfully - it seems Dick had found a knife that day, so

in defense of his life drew it on Ben killing him instantly. an infuriated mob rose upon him as by magic- Mr. Sweeney drew him into the store and he ran to the cellar & hid. they broke open the doors & windows. searched in every nook & corner yelling like demons. Some saying kill the women, burn the house etc at length they found him- dragged him out, beat & pounded & stabbed him. He was then got into Timmy Koontz' shoe store and the mob was kept at bay by John Brady and one or two others when Pa forced his way in to help- but a window was broken open and several rushed in. Pa seized one and kept him off a while, got pretty well pounded. the man threatening to use his revolver but Pa held his arms- untill several others got in at the window. pounded Dick with lasts and anything could hold of seized him and again dragged him out. this time Pa could not follow and thought he must be killed- but it was majestic to take him to jail. so they got a rope and started off dragging him. His mother and sister following and being insulted and spit upon. He managed to get the rope off his neck once and his mother slipped it off twice. by great efforts he was got into jail - where he is yet. Pa thinks he will get well, but O he is in a dreadful condition

Mr. Sweeney too had to flee for his life for they thought he had given him the knife and he had today given himself up and is in jail for safety. Dick's head & face are frightfully cut and bruised & swollen and the stab was in his bowels but not deep - the evening before Bob Morrow & John Lennox were drunk and Lennox shot Morrow, who is in a dying condition. yet the next day Lennox carried a McClellan banner in the procession and John Wolf was painted black to represent a negro - too drunk to know black from white-

Pa was very much agitated when he got home - saying O God I never saw such a thing in my life - the man he had was a stranger from Wheeling- they have often threatened to burn the town. Mr. Brady told once that but for him all the republican's houses would have been burnt. Much love to you all. I could tell you much more but cannot write it. Your loving mother- darling Johnny-

Ma

Dear Johnny, I have long wanted to sit
down and write you a full account of all 
my feelings & sufferings. but I would not 
trust myself- for you must know 
my darling. I was sadly hurt. for much to be  
endured any longer. I told you once I could 
not, but you never even said 'why mammy'-
then your last letter to Jane broke up the 
fountains and the water gushed forth in 
bitter tears -it was so bitter, so cruel, 
one need not have known by it,  you have 
a mother -but weeping has relieved my 
aching heart -the loving mother has triumphed 
and bid adieu to offended dignity-
and opens her arms and whole heart
to its beloved in the first place we will
go back a little- you must understand
that Sis & I had just returned from a pleasant
little visit. a great relief from our prison
home- friends had spared nothing to 
make our time agreeable - and of course
(you would not have it otherwise I know)
we were grateful to them -

As to Romaine she is dear as any of my children to me - and as to her husband, he is what any kind, gentlemanly, stranger would be to me,  separated from his wife. I knew your prejudices, but thought, when I told you how kind he had been to us,- under all the circumstances of the connection etc. that it would soften your feelings. I was much surprised however to see you get angry, and offended too, so I may have been led to say more than was meant, without qualifying or explanation which I would have done if I had the chance -but I was too sick -and it made me feel worse to think that you would not bear with me, when you might never see me again. I did not think I had given you just cause of offense - if I did darling forget it, you should have known, nothing or nobody could come between your mother's love &you - you do know I have no earthly thing but my very dear children and of course they are

all my happiness-I could not spare the love of one single one without being miserable now Johnny dear, when you can say 'Mammy dear I love you' do so. if you cannot, say nothing untill you can, as I could not endure it. I know that time will come - Sis is a dear good child and you would love her, if you knew her.  I do miss her so much, you know she is my baby - We had planned to visit you in the spring and on our return Jane was to go - but we cannot tell so long before hand - we may not all be here then - I have just had a letter from dear Franky he says they enjoyed their N. York turkeys very much - their Div. had 5,000 pounds - about 1 pound to a man - We had the thanksgiving dinner - Charlotte will have Christmas & Nanny N. year.  So we arrange our feasts - Annie had a tea party on Rose's birthday - the family & Mr & Mrs Brownson
unclear is gone to see Frank on his return - Sis will come home -

Dearest John
I sent the apple butter to Mrs Murray before your letter came - 5 quarts of apple butter - two of apple molasses, that Jane Potter made - she told me to be sure and tell you she made it. Also a can of sorghum syrup that Julius made.  He wanted to send more - but I thought you would rather have the other things and did not want to fill up the box too much.  I am taking music lessons - if you hear of any new pretty pieces - you must let me know-
Much love to you all keeping the lion's share to yourself.  As ever your truly loving Mother - this is all between you & me Jonny - and you can burn this as soon as you read it-

Decr 20th
Dear Johnny  I received your letter in due time but we have been in such an excited state we thought not of writing - for I believe we have not written you since the death of Dr. Reed he died a week ago of smallpox and tho' he had been sick some days there was no danger apprehended until the day he died.  He was thought to have varioloid [type of smallpox] but the eruption did not come out well and he sunk rapidly.  George went to Wheeling about two months ago and stays often. was taken with varioloid and they have had it in the family ever since.  Lill's baby had small pox - it had been vaccinated, like the rest, but the infection did not take - some were slightly sick, others more so - Ann McKennan went at first to be with her sister and to day I have heard that she has it - It was a very sad death - and under such painful circumstances -

for nobody could go to them, not even their own friends, Pa & Collin Reed went just in time to see him die - he was unconscious for some hours but before he became so expressed his readiness to die and his joyful experience of the presence of his saviour he was much loved and respected - active and useful in the Sunday school & church and the whole town seemed in grief- everybody has been vaccinated - we have not heard from Frank the last week. he was in the Raid upon Stony Creek - and wrote me after that but I suppose he was with Warren too.  I hope I shall get a letter this week but he wrote to Romaine that they were not giving furloughs now and he thought he could not come home for Christmas- we expect Sis on Thursday - Willie met with an accident that frightened us a good deal - the boys of the town were sledding down Main Str

he had been too - but now was standing to one side with his back to the sledders when a large sled with six boys came flying down, turned a little off the track and hit Willie and knocked him down senseless - on being carried home he was found to have a large bump on the back of his head and his knee, swollen and very painful and out of head all the evening - after a night's sleep his head was better - but his knee is still stiff and he cannot walk on it- it occurred 4 or 5 days ago.  Pa thinks it will get well- just had a letter from Frank was with Warren and is well but says nothing of coming home - says Grant don't recognise the necessity of going into winter quarters- Sandy Acheson is home. has resigned on account of his health -  John is with Sherman -

21st
I intended sending this yesterday but I wanted to send the children some Christmas money and could not get the chance. in the mean time I have been thinking we need not run the risk of sending money back & forth - you give them money for me & I will pay Mrs L. for you and settle the change so if you think that will do, give the three eldest 2 dollars each and the other two 1.  making 8. and add many good wishes & much love to give all my very dear children.  Your loving Mother

Oct. 4th
Dear Johnny- I have always intended you should have a whole letter to yourself but somehow it seems as tho we have really been too much occupied to write. After so long an absence, it took me a little while to realize that I was back again and have something to do. We look back upon our visit with much pleasure and some satisfaction more if I could believe I had done any body any good. For it distresses me to think I do so little good in the world- for after all what is there worth living for- but doing good. I think of you all over & over again- of the merry, happy, good dear children and wish myself back again- but as Jane Potter always says "I have no reason to complean". every body seemed so glad to see us and welcomed us so heartily it would have been very ungracious in us, not to be glad too.

and as yet- all remains quiet and pleasant. I did not see half enough of dear Janey, so you will have to pet her a little extra for me. Let me know as soon as she arrives- I couldn't help feeling a wee bit anxious. I am better, even than when I left you- I dreaded the journey and then enjoyed it much - even the sea sickness did not discourage me. I thought it would do me good and I believe it did. I continued to have diarrhea untill yesterday - but seemed to feel stronger & better. Dearest Johnny  It is a long time since I have written to you darling - but you know it was because writing to Jane was the same as writing to you - I was glad from you all - and that you are all thriving - but I was not glad to hear of so many dogs - rearing dogs seems such a low business, and yet I do know that my boys are not low - but somehow there is nothing elevating or improving in it but 'chacun  son got' [French: to each one his taste]- then Jane brings me such good accounts of those dear children - and realises my fond hopes for that darling boy Franky - Poor Jane I find her, very feeble - and diseased - I feel that she has been well cared for and is perhaps better than if she had remained at home for she was very much run down, and she looks better than she did - but she is quite a sufferer.  it was to know and judge for myself of the state of her health that I wanted to see her - I can stand twice as much as she can - I can rise at 5 or 6

and work pretty well untill noon - now - I am better the last 2 or 3 weeks - tho I am still subject to those sick spells and attacks of utter prostration- they pass off with 24 hours rest, but Jane is always weak & nervous- Romaine has just returned from Pittsburg and brought Mrs Manham? with her - Nicolas has bought a good gentle horse and nice comfortable carriage - they are all much pleased with the country - raising chickens, vegetables, etc   At last accounts our travellers were in Richmond enjoying the hospitality of the Gov.  Sis says the house is delightful and the grounds beautiful - but the Secesh don't pay them any attention - but they go sightseeing - they will go from there to the Salt Sulphur Springs in Monroe County and I don't know what route they will take home if Jane is well enough I will try to give or take her a little trip - if she don't get better I will apply to Pa- or Frank.

Mr & Mrs Le Clercq made us a visit lately - he thought my house could be sold - I told him I thought it might be conveyed & secured by a written promise from each heir to give a deed on my death - would that do?  he offers 2500 - we did ask 300 but the other thing is always needing repairs and now the authorities are having the streets cut down so that the front door will be upstairs almost and a new pavement have to be made, etc. the rent this year after deducting all taxes amounts to $37-42!!  rather slim - it is now rented by the month - you could draw up a paper that all could sign - have you heard of the Virginia lands? Mr Dahlgren & Mr Wills both thought there was something wrong - Mr Alex Acheson is of the same opinion - but I think Dr. N would horaly [meaning:hourly] wrong us wilfully-  can you manage or direct the sale of the house - I am to let him know soon - Charlotte & Sis will probably be back in 2 weeks - Annie told me she wanted to send Julius one of her nice hams - their own raising & curing - perfectly healthy and good. one of my fancies has been ham - now it is young raw onions with parsley and vinegar two morning & at noon.  I never taste them at all after eating them - we are just  beginning to have strawberries - we buy them at 30 cts - we shall have a very few peaches but enough apples to do - much love to you all.  my very dear children - Your loving Mother
